titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Baruch Nadel Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Diane E. Kaplan and Laurie R. Cohen

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday January 10, 2019 at 10:51

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers consist of Baruch Nadel's research materials for a proposed book on Abraham Stern, the founder of Lohamei Herut Israel ("Lehi"), an armed underground organization in British Palestine. The papers include more than 150 transcribed interviews conducted by Nadel, interviews by others with members of Lehi, memoirs by Lehi members and Stern aides, and poems and letters by Stern. Also included in the papers are Nadel's research materials concerning the emigration of Jews from Iraq between 1950 and 1951 and collected materials relating to Jewish life in Europe and to Nadel's father, MenahÌ£em Nadel, and others involved in early Zionist political groups, Palestine under the Mandate, and the State of Israel.

langmaterial.language: Most of the papers are in Hebrew, with smaller quantities in English and Arabic.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Audio cassettes of Nadel's interviews with Hillel Kook are in the Historical Sound Recordings Collection in the Yale University Library.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research. Series II was opened to research in 2014; prior to that it was restricted under a donor-imposed access restriction.
Researchers are required to use the microfilm edition of the papers, call number HM208, except for Box 9 and the additions which were not filmed.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Baruch Nadel Papers (MS 1393). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: The papers (excluding Box 9 and the additions) are also available on microfilm (8 reels, 35mm.) from Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library, at cost. Order no. HM208.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Baruch Nadel was born in Palestine on February 10, 1926. He was a member of the Haganah from 1942 to 1947, studied mathematics at the Hebrew University from 1945 to 1947, and joined the Lohamei Herut Israel ("Lehi") in 1948. Nadel served with the Israeli Defense Forces from 1951 to 1953. From 1957 to 1967 he was the manager of Nadel Advertising and in 1968 he joined the staff of the newspaper Yediot Aharonot. He is the author of books on Israeli history and politics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Baruch Nadel Papers consist of research materials collected by Nadel for use in his proposed studies of Abraham Stern and of the mass emigration of Jews from Iraq to Israel in 1950 and 1951. The papers also include correspondence, writings, printed material, and other documents pertaining to Baruch Nadel's father, Menahem Nadel, the Labor Zionist movement, and Israeli history. The bulk of the material is composed of interviews and documents relating to Abraham Stern, the founder of Lohamei Herut Israel ('Lehi'), an armed underground organization founded in 1940 which directed its activities against the British Mandatory authorities in Palestine. Though the papers include printed books, pamphlets, newspapers, and other materials dating from 1918 on, the bulk of the papers date after 1969. Series I, Abraham Stern files, is the largest of the three series.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The papers are arranged in three series: I. Abraham Stern Files, 1929-1985. II. Iraqi Jewish Immigration Files, 1949-1985. III. Other Papers, 1918-1985, and two additions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Nadel joined 'Lehi' in 1948 and began collecting documents about its history at that time. In 1970 Nadel decided to write a book about Stern and began a concentrated effort to collect materials and to interview persons concerning Stern, Lehi, and other underground resistance to British control of Palestine in the 1940s. Series I is composed of these materials, which Nadel gave to the Library in 1984 and 1985 and which have been left in the order established by Nadel.

Series I begins with the testimonies of about 165 people interviewed by Nadel, either in person or by telephone. In most cases the interviewees reviewed and corrected Nadel's transcriptions of their interviews. Folders 1-24 contain these transcriptions as well as other materials gathered about the interviewee. Throughout the series Nadel has interspersed explanatory notes in Hebrew. Interview files are arranged and listed by personal name; however, not all materials by or about a person are in the same folder. For example, Nadel's interview with Stern's wife Rony Borshtien-Zamir is in folder 3, but an interview with Rony Stern made by Israeli television is in folder 13. The listing gives both the Hebrew description and an English translation along with a romanization of the Hebrew names based on standard Library of Congress cataloging practice. This spelling of names in roman characters may vary from spellings used in other sources. For instance, though Nadel refers in his notes to Hillel Kook, the listing gives his name as Hillel Ḳuḳ. Folders 25-28 contain several published volumes of memoirs of other underground members and two books of poems and songs by Stern. The volumes include short notes by Nadel. The contents of boxes 1-3 were donated in 1984. (Three audio cassettes of Nadel's interviews with Hillel Kook are in the Historical Sound Recordings Collection.)

Boxes 4 and 5 are composed of more than 500 additional documents concerning Stern, which Nadel added to the papers in 1985. These documents include copies of Stern's letters, articles and poems by him, letters from people interviewed by Nadel, clippings, pamphlets, and photographs, and additional interviews and books. Nadel gave an arbitrary number to each document so as to be able to identify them in the explanations he wrote. These explanations are in folder 29 and serve as an inventory to the contents of boxes 4 and 5.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Boxes 1-3 contain materials arranged by record type. Materials in boxes 4 and 5 are arranged in numerical order.

did.unittitle: Note to the book of Daṿid Ha-Cohen
Yaʾir to H. Sh. HaLeṿi, postcards
3 postcards from Yaʾir to Ḥanah Dimenṭ
Memoirs of ʾAriah Ḳotser on Yaʾir

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II, Iraqi Jewish immigration files, contains over 500 documents collected by Nadel after he was asked to write a book on the mass emigration of Jews from Iraq to Israel in 1950-1951. The documents include interviews, printed materials, and copies of government records which chronicle Jewish life in Iraq, the history of illegal immigration in the 1940s, and the events which brought about the mass exodus.

Nadel asserts that his collections of documents sheds light on a conspiracy in which the governments of Iraq, Israel, the United States, and Great Britain worked together to force the Jews of Iraq to immigrate to Israel. He further contends that leaders of the Zionist movement in Palestine and the new Israeli government attempted to create suspicions about "Zionist agents" among Iraqi Jews; that the United States government aided in efforts to transfer to Israel middle class Iraqi Jews, who formed a nucleus of the Iraqi Communist Party; and that the Israeli government secretly organized attacks on Iraqi Jewish businesses in order to scare Iraqi Jews into leaving the country.

The documents are arranged in numerical order according to the arbitrary numbers assigned to them by Nadel. Nadel's sources included the files of the Jewish Agency which was responsible for the immigration of Iraqi Jews, and members of the Israeli secret service. His notes which explain the background for his research and describe the importance of individual documents are in folder 54. These notes also serve as an inventory to the series.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials in this series are arranged in numerical order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III, Other papers, is composed of correspondence, writings, printed material and other documents which relate to Nadel's father, Menahem Nadel, and others involved in early Zionist political groups. The papers also contain materials Nadel collected concerning Palestine under the Mandate and State of Israel, 1918-1985.

The materials are arranged in folders as Nadel organized them. Within each folder in box 8, Nadel has included his own notes, in Hebrew, explaining the significance of individual items. Items within the folders have been arranged to insure proper long term storage and may not appear in exactly the same order as described by Nadel in his folder notes.

Folder 76 contains Menahem Nadel's biographical memoir of his involvement in he-Ḥalutz and the Labor Zionist youth movement in Russia and other documents relating to this movement. Materials in folder 77 also document Zionist youth work, particularly that inspired by Ber Borochov. The file contains items about ha-Noar and ha-Hugim ha-Marksistim b'Erets Yi'sra'el, issues of be-Mefneh , volumes issed by Sefriyah Marksistit of which Menaḥem Nadel was an editor, and writings by him. Printed copies of articles by Chaim Arlosoroff are in folder 79 along with scattered documents concerning plans to rescue Rumanian Jews in 1944 and issues of a socialist youth group newsletter ha-Degel
ha-Adom . The writings of Sholom Shlogar are included in pamphlets and issues of he-Ḥevrah in folder 80. Folder 81 contains additional printed material, clippings, and photographs relating to Lehi and Abraham Stern. Series III also includes a rare Israeli stamp issued prior to May, 1948. A xerox copy of the stamp is included in folder 82.
Box 9 contains four volumes of the journal Sulam from 1949 to 1952. The journal, a monthly general periodical, reflects the thoughts of the Ḥerut Party in Israel.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The material in this series remains in the order established by Baruch Nadel. Each folder in box 8 contains explanatory notes by Nadel concerning the contents of that folder.

odd.head: General
odd.p: This material has not been microfilmed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This addition is composed of brochures, posters, reports, and other types of printed material, as well as photographs, which document Jewish life in many locations. The materials are arranged by country of origin. One folder at the end of the addition contains additional photographs of Abraham Stern.
